p53 and p63 belong to a family of sequence-specific transcription factors regulating key cellular processes. Differential composition of the p53 and p63 DNA-binding sites may contribute to distinct functions of these protein homologues. We used SELEX (systematic evolution of ligands by exponential enrichment) methodology to identify nucleic acid ligands for p63. We found that p63 bound preferentially to DNA fragments conforming to the 20 bp sequence 5′-RRRC(A/G)(A/T)GYYYRRRC(A/T)(C/T)GYYY-3′. Relative to the p53 consensus, the p63 consensus DNA-binding site (DBS) was more degenerate, particularly at positions 10 and 11, and was enriched for A/G at position 5 and C/T at position 16 of the consensus. The differences in DNA-binding site preferences between p63 and p53 influenced their ability to activate transcription from select response elements (REs) in cells. A computer algorithm, p63MH, was developed to find candidate p63-binding motifs on input sequences. We identified genes responsive to p63 regulation that contain functional p63 REs. Our results suggest that the sequence composition of REs could be one contributing factor to target gene discrimination between p63 and p53.

RASSF1A (RAS-association domain family 1, isoform A) is a newer tumor suppressor that binds to and stabilizes microtubules as well as induces M-phase cell cycle arrest. Several other proteins that interact with and stabilize microtubules also undergo mitotic phase phosphorylation to regulate microtubule dynamics and M-phase cell cycle progression. Currently, however, there is a paucity of information regarding the phosphorylation status of RASSF1A and its regulation during mitosis. In this study, for the first time, we demonstrate that Aurora-A is a RASSF1A kinase and, to the best of our knowledge, this is also the first study reporting the identification of a kinase for RASSF1A. We show that the mitotic kinase Aurora-A directly interacts with and phosphorylates RASSF1 and that RASSF1A is phosphorylated by Aurora-A during mitosis. These findings therefore link an important oncogenic mitotic kinase to regulate RASSF1A tumor suppressor. Aurora-A appears to phosphorylate RASSF1A at Threonine202 and/or Serine203 that reside within the known microtubule-binding domain of RASSF1A. Substitutions of these residues with glutamic acid at both positions, mimicking constitutive phosphorylation of RASSF1A, disrupt RASSF1A interactions with microtubules and abolish its ability to induce M-phase cell cycle arrest. Our results further demonstrate that Aurora-A overexpression also interferes with RASSF1A-mediated growth suppression. In view of our results, we propose that Aurora-A-mediated phosphorylation of RASSF1A is a novel mechanism that regulates the ability of this tumor suppressor to interact with microtubules and modulate M-phase cell cycle progression.

DEXD/H-box protein UAP56 is an essential pre-mRNA splicing factor required for the first ATP-dependent spliceosome assembly step. UAP56 is also essential for the export of the majority of mRNAs from the nucleus to the cytoplasm. We performed biochemical characterization of UAP56’s ATPase and helicase activity, which is important for further understanding the role of these activities in UAP56’s function. We showed that UAP56 is an RNA-stimulated ATPase that can only hydrolyze ATP. We demonstrated that UAP56 is an ATP-dependent RNA helicase that can unwind substrates with 5′ or 3′ overhangs or blunt ends in vitro. We showed that U2AF65 and Aly, two proteins known to interact with UAP56, do not influence UAP56’s ATPase or helicase activity. We also demonstrated that several mutants in the conserved helicase motifs I, II, and III abolish UAP56’s ATPase and/or helicase activity, providing tools for future investigation of the role of UAP56’s ATPase and helicase activity in spliceosome assembly and mRNA export. DEXD/H-box protein UAP56 is an essential pre-mRNA splicing factor required for the first ATP-dependent spliceosome assembly step. UAP56 is also essential for the export of the majority of mRNAs from the nucleus to the cytoplasm. We performed biochemical characterization of UAP56’s ATPase and helicase activity, which is important for further understanding the role of these activities in UAP56’s function. We showed that UAP56 is an RNA-stimulated ATPase that can only hydrolyze ATP. We demonstrated that UAP56 is an ATP-dependent RNA helicase that can unwind substrates with 5′ or 3′ overhangs or blunt ends in vitro. We showed that U2AF65 and Aly, two proteins known to interact with UAP56, do not influence UAP56’s ATPase or helicase activity. We also demonstrated that several mutants in the conserved helicase motifs I, II, and III abolish UAP56’s ATPase and/or helicase activity, providing tools for future investigation of the role of UAP56’s ATPase and helicase activity in spliceosome assembly and mRNA export. Biochemical characterization of the ATPase and helicase activity of UAP56, an essential pre-mRNA splicing and mRNA export factor.Journal of Biological ChemistryVol. 285Issue 26PreviewVOLUME 282 (2007) PAGES 22544–22550 Full-Text PDF Open Access Pre-mRNA splicing is a critical event in the eukaryotic gene expression pathway. In eukaryotes, DNA is first transcribed to pre-mRNAs, which often contain introns. These introns need to be precisely removed by pre-mRNA splicing before mRNA can be exported from the nucleus and translated. Pre-mRNA splicing is carried out by the spliceosome, a large protein-RNA complex that contains five small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (U1, U2, U4, U5, and U6) and numerous other protein factors (1Moore M.J. Query C.C. Sharp P.A. Gesteland R. Atkins J. The RNA World. 1993: 303-357Google Scholar, 2Hastings M.L. Krainer A.R. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 2001; 13: 302-309Crossref PubMed Scopus (387) Google Scholar, 3Nilsen T.W. BioEssays. 2003; 25: 1147-1149Crossref PubMed Scopus (285) Google Scholar). The spliceosome assembles on pre-mRNA in a stepwise manner by forming the E, A, B, and C complexes. The E complex formation involves the recognition of the 5′ splice site, the branch point sequence, the polypyrimidine tract, and the 3′ splice site by the U1 snRNP, 2The abbreviations used are: snRNP, small nuclear ribonucleoproteins; snRNA, small nuclear RNA; ds, double-stranded; nt, nucleotide; GST, glutathione S-transferase; AMPPNP, 5′-adenylyl-β,γ-imidodiphosphate; ATP-γ-S, adenosine 5′-O-(thiotriphosphate); h, human. SF1, U2AF65, and U2AF35, respectively. The U2 snRNP then base-pairs with the branch point sequence and forms the A complex in an ATP-dependent manner. The subsequent joining of the U4/U6.U5 tri-snRNP signifies the formation of the B complex. After extensive rearrangements of protein-RNA and RNA-RNA interactions, the catalytically active C complex forms. Later evidence shows that the spliceosome containing all five snRNPs may preassemble before encountering any pre-mRNA substrates (4Stevens S.W. Ryan D.E. Ge H.Y. Moore R.E. Young M.K. Lee T.D. Abelson J. Mol. Cell. 2002; 9: 31-44Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (211) Google Scholar, 5Malca H. Shomron N. Ast G. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2003; 23: 3442-3455Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). Interactions in the traditional stepwise assembly model are usually observed under stringent conditions, which may reflect a stepwise strengthening of particular interactions in the preassembled spliceosome (6Nilsen T.W. Mol. Cell. 2002; 9: 8-9Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar); therefore the traditional model continues to serve as a practical tool for understanding spliceosome assembly. With the exception of the formation of the E complex, all of the spliceosome assembly steps require ATP. Coinciding with this ATP dependence is the association of a number of DEXD/H-box proteins that are thought to facilitate various stages of the assembly process, possibly using the energy of ATP hydrolysis (7Staley J.P. Guthrie C. Cell. 1998; 92: 315-326Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (914) Google Scholar). DEXD/H-box proteins belong to the superfamily 2 of the helicase superfamilies and contain 9–11 conserved helicase motifs (8Cordin O. Banroques J. Tanner N.K. Linder P. Gene (Amst.). 2006; 367: 17-37Crossref PubMed Scopus (739) Google Scholar, 9Sengoku T. Nureki O. Nakamura A. Kobayashi S. Yokoyama S. Cell. 2006; 125: 287-300Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (448) Google Scholar). DEXD/H-box proteins are present in almost all cellular events that involve RNA. The sequence similarity between DEXD/H-box proteins and well characterized DNA helicases lead to the early hypothesis that DEXD/H-box proteins function in various cellular processes as RNA helicases. Many DEXD/H-box proteins have been shown to have ATPase activity, although the strength of their ATPase activity varies widely (kcat from 0.3/min to 600/min) (8Cordin O. Banroques J. Tanner N.K. Linder P. Gene (Amst.). 2006; 367: 17-37Crossref PubMed Scopus (739) Google Scholar). A subset of the DEXD/H-box proteins have been shown to unwind dsRNA in vitro (9Sengoku T. Nureki O. Nakamura A. Kobayashi S. Yokoyama S. Cell. 2006; 125: 287-300Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (448) Google Scholar, 10Rogers Jr., G.W. Komar A.A. Merrick W.C. Prog. Nucleic Acid Res. Mol. Biol. 2002; 72: 307-331Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 11Yang Q. Jankowsky E. Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 2006; 13: 981-986Crossref PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar, 12Wagner J.D. Jankowsky E. Company M. Pyle A.M. Abelson J.N. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 2926-2937Crossref PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar, 13Wang Y. Wagner J.D. Guthrie C. Curr. Biol. 1998; 8: 441-451Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar, 14Tanaka N. Schwer B. Biochemistry. 2006; 45: 6510-6521Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). Increasing evidence shows that DEXD/H-box proteins can fulfill their cellular function using different approaches instead of being a helicase alone. On the one hand, eIF4A, a prototypic DEXD/H-box protein, unwinds dsRNA, and its helicase activity is likely to be important for its role in translation initiation (15Jaramillo M. Dever T.E. Merrick W.C. Sonenberg N. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1991; 11: 5992-5997Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar, 16Sonenberg N. Gene Expr. 1993; 3: 317-323PubMed Google Scholar, 17Svitkin Y.V. Pause A. Haghighat A. Pyronnet S. Witherell G. Belsham G.J. Sonenberg N. RNA (Cold Spring Harbor). 2001; 7: 382-394Google Scholar). On the other hand, the ATPase activity of eIF4AIII is inhibited in the exon junction complex, so it can hold the exon junction complex tightly on a single-stranded RNA (18Ballut L. Marchadier B. Baguet A. Tomasetto C. Seraphin B. Le Hir H. Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 2005; 12: 861-869Crossref PubMed Scopus (249) Google Scholar, 19Bono F. Ebert J. Lorentzen E. Conti E. Cell. 2006; 126: 713-725Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (317) Google Scholar, 20Andersen C.B. Ballut L. Johansen J.S. Chamieh H. Nielsen K.H. Oliveira C.L. Pedersen J.S. Seraphin B. Le Hir H. Andersen G.R. Science. 2006; 313: 1968-1972Crossref PubMed Scopus (324) Google Scholar). In addition, several DEXD/H-box proteins are shown to be able to displace protein factors from single-stranded RNA without duplex unwinding (RNPase activity), which may serve as another way for DEXD/H-box protein to fulfill their cellular functions (21Fairman M.E. Maroney P.A. Wang W. Bowers H.A. Gollnick P. Nilsen T.W. Jankowsky E. Science. 2004; 304: 730-734Crossref PubMed Scopus (201) Google Scholar). Biochemical characterization of DEXD/H-box proteins’ enzymatic activity has often been the first step for understanding the function of these proteins in the cellular processes they involve. Our focus in this study is to characterize the biochemical properties of DEXD/H-box protein UAP56. UAP56 is an essential splicing factor first discovered through its interactions with U2AF65 (22Fleckner J. Zhang M. Valcarcel J. Green M.R. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 1864-1872Crossref PubMed Scopus (213) Google Scholar). UAP56 is one of the two DEXD/H-box proteins, together with Prp5, required for the first ATP-dependent spliceosome assembly step (the binding of U2 snRNP to the branch point sequence). HeLa nuclear extract depleted of UAP56 cannot support the formation of A complex in vitro (22Fleckner J. Zhang M. Valcarcel J. Green M.R. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 1864-1872Crossref PubMed Scopus (213) Google Scholar). The mechanism of how UAP56 facilitates splicing is unknown. One possibility is that UAP56 acts as an RNA helicase and rearranges secondary structures in U2 snRNA that may be critical for the binding of U2 snRNP to branch point sequence. A similar role has been proposed for Prp5 (23O'Day C.L. Dalbadie-McFarland G. Abelson J. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 33261-33267Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (97) Google Scholar). However, UAP56 has not been demonstrated to be able to unwind dsRNA in vitro, and it is not clear whether the helicase activity is required for the formation of the A complex. An alternative possibility is that UAP56 promotes the removal of U2AF65 from the 3′ splice site region, consequently facilitating the binding of U2 snRNP to the pre-mRNA (24Kistler A.L. Guthrie C. Genes Dev. 2001; 15: 42-49Crossref PubMed Scopus (165) Google Scholar). Support for this hypothesis mainly comes from yeast genetic analyses, and there is not yet evidence whether UAP56 can remove U2AF65 from RNA in vitro. UAP56 has also been shown to be essential for mRNA export in several organisms (25Macmorris M. Brocker C. Blumenthal T. RNA (Cold Spring Harbor). 2003; 9: 847-857Google Scholar, 26Herold A. Teixeira L. Izaurralde E. EMBO J. 2003; 22: 2472-2483Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar, 27Jensen T.H. Boulay J. Rosbash M. Libri D. Curr. Biol. 2001; 11: 1711-1715Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (132) Google Scholar). mRNA export is thought to be mediated through a heterodimeric transport receptor (NXF1-p15), which binds the RNA cargo directly or indirectly and transports the cargo through the nuclear pore complex. mRNA export analyses in Drosophila indicates that UAP56 and NXF1-p15 acts in the same pathway and is responsible for the export of the majority of mRNAs (26Herold A. Teixeira L. Izaurralde E. EMBO J. 2003; 22: 2472-2483Crossref PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar). Knockdown of UAP56 in Caenorhabditis elegans leads to a drastic reduction of green fluorescent protein reporter gene expression due to accumulation of mRNA in the nucleus (25Macmorris M. Brocker C. Blumenthal T. RNA (Cold Spring Harbor). 2003; 9: 847-857Google Scholar). Yra1, an essential export factor in yeast, interacts with Sub2 (the yeast UAP56 homolog) and Mex67-Mtr2 (the yeast NXF1-p15 homolog) and is thought to be the adaptor protein between Sub2 and Mex67-Mtr2 (28Strasser K. Hurt E. Nature. 2001; 413: 648-652Crossref PubMed Scopus (223) Google Scholar). Aly, the Yra1 analog in higher eukaryotes, also interacts with UAP56, although Aly is not essential for mRNA export in higher eukaryotes (25Macmorris M. Brocker C. Blumenthal T. RNA (Cold Spring Harbor). 2003; 9: 847-857Google Scholar, 29Gatfield D. Izaurralde E. J. Cell Biol. 2002; 159: 579-588Crossref PubMed Scopus (170) Google Scholar), suggesting the existence of other adaptor proteins. In addition, both UAP56 and Aly are part of the Trex complex that is thought to couple transcription and mRNA export (30Strasser K. Masuda S. Mason P. Pfannstiel J. Oppizzi M. Rodriguez-Navarro S. Rondon A.G. Aguilera A. Struhl K. Reed R. Hurt E. Nature. 2002; 417: 304-308Crossref PubMed Scopus (645) Google Scholar). It is unknown whether UAP56’s ATPase or helicase activity is required for its function in mRNA export. Human UAP56 is 428 residues in length and has 35% sequence identity to eIF4A (395 residues), a prototypic DEXD/H-box protein involved in translation initiation. UAP56 and eIF4A both contain the minimal helicase core (∼400 amino acids) without any additional domains. The crystal structure of UAP56 shows that UAP56 is composed of an N-terminal and C-terminal domain connected with a flexible liner (31Zhao R. Shen J. Green M.R. MacMorris M. Blumenthal T. Structure (Camb.). 2004; 12: 1373-1381Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar, 32Shi H. Cordin O. Minder C.M. Linder P. Xu R.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2004; 101: 17628-17633Crossref PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar). Both domains have a typical RecA-like fold with seven parallel β-strands surrounded by α-helices on both sides. The N-terminal domain contains conserved helicase motifs Q, I, Ia, GG, Ib, II, and III, whereas the C-terminal domain contains helicase motifs IV, QXXR, V, and VI. The overall fold of each RecA-like domain is similar to that of eIF4A. The structure and sequence similarity suggest that UAP56 may have similar enzymatic properties as eIF4A, although there has not been much biochemical characterization of UAP56. We demonstrate in this study that UAP56 is an RNA-stimulated ATPase. UAP56 unwinds dsRNA in vitro in an ATP-dependent manner. The ATPase and helicase activities of UAP56 are weak and are not influenced by two protein factors (U2AF65 and Aly) that are known to interact with UAP56. We demonstrate that a number of UAP56 mutants in the conserved helicase motifs I, II, and III are defective in ATPase and/or helicase activity, providing tools for further study of the roles of these activities in UAP56's function in pre-mRNA splicing and mRNA export. Human UAP56 is subcloned in pGEX-KG as a GST fusion protein and expressed in Escherichia coli strain BL21(DE3). Bacteria were grown to A600 of 0.4–0.6 followed by the addition of 0.2 mm isopropyl-β-d-thiogalactoside to induce protein expression at room temperature overnight. Bacteria were harvested by centrifugation and lysed with sonication. GST-UAP56 was first purified by glutathione resin. GST was then cleaved off with thrombin, and UAP56 was further purified using a Superdex 200 (S200) gel filtration column. Human U2AF65 d63 (the N-terminal 62 residues deleted) was expressed and purified in a similar manner as UAP56 (see Fig. 1a). GST-Aly was also expressed and purified from E. coli and was a generous gift from B. Erickson and Dr. D. Bentley at the University of Colorado at Denver and Health Sciences Center (see Fig. 1a). All ATPase reactions were performed under the following conditions unless otherwise stated. The reaction mixture (20 μl) contains 2 μm UAP56 (wild type or mutants), trace amounts of [α-32P]ATP, 50 μm cold ATP, 50 μm U30 (30-nt poly(U)) in a buffer containing 50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 8.5, 50 mm KCl, 2 mm MgCl2, 0.1 mg/ml bovine serum albumin, and 1 mm dithiothreitol. The reaction was incubated at 37 °C for 30 min and stopped with 2 μl of 100 mm EDTA. 4 μl of the reaction mixture was spotted onto a TLC plate, which was developed in a buffer containing 2 m acetic acid and 0.5 m LiCl2 for 1.5 h to separate ADP and ATP. The amount of ATP hydrolyzed was quantified using a PhosphorImager. Error bars in all figures in this study represent standard deviations derived from independently repeated experiments. For kinetic analyses, 0.5 μm UAP56 was incubated with trace amounts of [α-32P]ATP, 20 μm U30, and 5–100 μm cold ATP in the aforementioned buffer at 37 °C. The reaction remains linear for at least 10 min, and the hydrolysis rate for 10 min was used as the initial hydrolysis rate for kinetic analyses. Initial hydrolysis rates were plotted against cold ATP concentrations and fitted to the Michaelis-Menten equation using KaleidaGraph to obtain Vmax and Km values. Preparation of the dsRNA Substrates—All single-stranded RNAs used in this study were ordered from Integrated DNA Technologies. One strand of the substrate was labeled at the 5′ end with [γ-32P]ATP (GE Healthcare) using polynucleotide kinase at 37 °C for 1 h. The reaction mixture was boiled for 5 min to inactivate polynucleotide kinase. The complementary strand was added to reach a molar ratio of 1:1.2 between the labeled and the unlabeled complementary strand. The reaction mixture was boiled for 3 min and cooled to room temperature in 3 h. Labeled dsRNA was purified using a G-25 spin column (GE Healthcare) to remove excess [γ-32P]ATP. Helicase Reaction—All helicase reactions were performed under the following conditions unless otherwise stated. The reaction mixture (20 μl) contained 20 mm Tris-HCl pH 8.5, 50 mm KCl, 65 mm NaCl, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 10% glycerol, 0.4 units/μl ribonuclease inhibitor (Fisher), 3 mm ATP, 100 nm unlabeled complementary strand (“trap” RNA) (9Sengoku T. Nureki O. Nakamura A. Kobayashi S. Yokoyama S. Cell. 2006; 125: 287-300Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (448) Google Scholar), 2.5 nm labeled dsRNA substrate, and 4 μm UAP56. After incubation at 37 °C for 30 min, the reaction was terminated with 5 μl of stop solution (50% glycerol, 0.5% SDS, 100 mm EDTA, 0.1% bromphenol blue, 0.1% xylene cyanol) followed by treatment with 0.7 μl of proteinase K (900 units/mol) at room temperature for 3 min. The unwound ssRNA was separated from the dsRNA substrate using native PAGE on a 16% polyacrylamide gel. The amount of dsRNA and ssRNA was quantified using a PhosphorImager. The percentage of unwinding was calculated using the following formula: % unwinding = counts for ssRNA/(counts for dsRNA + counts for ssRNA). Background unwinding in the absence of UAP56 (typically 5–10%) was subtracted from the actual percentage of unwinding. It is worth noting that the addition of trap RNA is not absolutely required for the helicase reaction. The maximum percentage of unwinding after 30 min incubation at 37 °C is only slightly lower (∼10%) without the trap RNA (data not shown). UAP56 Is an RNA-stimulated ATPase—We first examined UAP56’s ATPase activity. Human UAP56 was expressed as a GST fusion protein in E. coli. GST-UAP56 was first purified with glutathione resin. GST was then cleaved with thrombin, and the resultant UAP56 was further purified using gel filtration chromatography (Fig. 1a). Purified UAP56 was incubated at 37 °C with a trace amount of [α-32P]ATP and varied amounts of cold ATP. ADP and ATP were separated on a TLC plate, and the amount of ATP hydrolyzed was quantified on a PhosphorImager (Fig. 1b). We found that without RNA, UAP56 has very low ATP hydrolysis in 30 min (Fig. 1c). ATP hydrolysis is stimulated 20-fold in the presence of 50 μm U30 (30-nt poly(U)) (Fig. 1c). Shorter poly(U) (U25) and poly(C) (C30 and C25), as well as three RNAs with arbitrary sequences (RNA1, RNA2, and R13, see Table 1 for sequences), stimulate the ATPase activity to a similar degree (17–23-fold) (Fig. 1c). dsRNA also stimulate UAP56’s ATPase activity, although to a lesser extent (6–8-fold) (Fig. 1c).TABLE 1RNAs used in this studyNameLengthSequence (5′ to 3′)ntRNA125UUUAGUACUCUAGUCCCUUUUUAUARNA240AAUUCCCUUAUAAAAAGGGACUAGAGUACUAAAUGUUUCURNA330CCUUAUAAAAAGGGACUAGAGUACUAAAUGRNA3C30CAUUUAGUACUCUAGUCCCUUUUUAUAAGGR1313GCUUUACGGUGCUR13C13AGCACCGUAAAGCR23-5′23AAAACAAAAUAGCACCGUAAAGCaUnderline indicates the region that base pairs with R13R23-3′23GCUUUACGGUGCUUAAAACAAAAbUnderline indicates the region that base pairs with R13CR1414ACUCUAGUCCCUUUR14C14AAAGGGACUAGAGUR2020GCUUUACGGUGCUAUUUUGUR20C20ACAAAAUAGCACCGUAAAGCa Underline indicates the region that base pairs with R13b Underline indicates the region that base pairs with R13C Open table in a new tab The RNA stimulation of ATPase activity is common to DEXD/H-box proteins and has been observed in other DEXD/H-box proteins including those involved in pre-mRNA splicing. For example, eIF4A’s ATPase activity is stimulated 10–14-fold in the presence of poly(U), poly(A), or poly(C) (33Abramson R.D. Dever T.E. Lawson T.G. Ray B.K. Thach R.E. Merrick W.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 3826-3832Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Prp16’s ATPase activity is stimulated 8–9-fold by poly(A) and 4–5-fold by poly(U) (34Schwer B. Guthrie C. Nature. 1991; 349: 494-499Crossref PubMed Scopus (249) Google Scholar). The initial rate of hydrolysis of Prp22 was stimulated 2.5–4-fold by various RNAs (12Wagner J.D. Jankowsky E. Company M. Pyle A.M. Abelson J.N. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 2926-2937Crossref PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar, 35Schwer B. Gross C.H. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 2086-2094Crossref PubMed Scopus (190) Google Scholar). Interestingly, Prp5’s ATPase activity is stimulated by RNAs in a sequence-dependent manner. Poly(U) was best able to stimulate Prp5’s ATPase activity, whereas poly(A) and poly(C) demonstrate little or no stimulation (23O'Day C.L. Dalbadie-McFarland G. Abelson J. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 33261-33267Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (97) Google Scholar). Furthermore, U2 snRNA better stimulates Prp5’s ATPase activity than other snRNAs and homopolymers, suggesting a mechanism for the specificity of Prp5’s function in the spliceosome assembly. We found that the ATPase activity of UAP56 is similarly stimulated by various RNAs (17–23-fold) without sequence specificity, similar to eIF4A, Prp16, and Prp22 but differing from Prp5. We performed steady state kinetic analysis of UAP56’s ATPase activity with 0.5 μm UAP56 in the presence of 20 μm U30 (Fig. 1d). Fitting the data to the Michaelis-Menten equation using KaleidaGraph generated a Vmax of 0.126 ± 0.003 μm/min and Km of 3.3 ± 0.5 μm. Since the kinetic analyses were performed with 0.5 μm UAP56, these data indicate that UAP56 has a kcat of 0.25 ± 0.01/min, similar to eIF4A (0.3/min) under similar conditions (36Abramson R.D. Dever T.E. Merrick W.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 6016-6019Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 37Pause A. Sonenberg N. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 2643-2654Crossref PubMed Scopus (532) Google Scholar). Lorsch and Herschlag (38Lorsch J.R. Herschlag D. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 2194-2206Crossref PubMed Scopus (135) Google Scholar) found that the kcat of eIF4A’s ATPase activity increased 10-fold (3/min) in the presence of large amounts of poly(U) (475 μm). In the case of UAP56, we did not observe significant increase in ATPase activity with poly(U) concentration higher than 20 μm (Fig. 1c). We further examined whether UAP56 can hydrolyze NTPs other than ATP. We performed the ATPase assay in the presence of increasing concentrations of cold ATP, GTP, CTP, and TTP (Fig. 1e). Cold ATP can be hydrolyzed and efficiently compete with the amount of [α-32P]ATP hydrolyzed, whereas cold GTP, CTP, and TTP cannot be hydrolyzed. UAP56 Unwinds dsRNA in Vitro—We first examined whether UAP56 can unwind dsRNA in vitro using a 13-nt blunt end RNA duplex with arbitrary sequence (designated R13/R13C, see Table 1 for sequences) (9Sengoku T. Nureki O. Nakamura A. Kobayashi S. Yokoyama S. Cell. 2006; 125: 287-300Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (448) Google Scholar, 39Rogers Jr., G.W. Lima W.F. Merrick W.C. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 12598-12608Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar). UAP56 clearly unwinds this dsRNA in a protein concentration-dependent manner (Fig. 2a). The helicase activity is weak, and a large amount of UAP56 (0.5 μm or higher) is needed to observe significant unwinding. The weak helicase activity is common to DEXD/H-box helicases, and large amounts of proteins are routinely used for helicase assay of DEXD/H-box proteins. For example, 0.8 μm protein was used for eIF4A’s helicase assay that produces a roughly 35% unwinding of dsRNA with the same substrate (39Rogers Jr., G.W. Lima W.F. Merrick W.C. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 12598-12608Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar). 10 μm protein was used to demonstrate the helicase activity of the minimum helicase core of Vasa (9Sengoku T. Nureki O. Nakamura A. Kobayashi S. Yokoyama S. Cell. 2006; 125: 287-300Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (448) Google Scholar). We performed time course analysis of UAP56’s helicase activity. Due to the large amount of UAP56 concentration needed to observe significant duplex unwinding (>>substrate concentration), we cannot perform steady state kinetic analyses to measure Km and kcat. However, it is clear that UAP56 unwinds an increasing amount of dsRNA with time (Fig. 2b). The amount of unwinding reaches saturation at 30 min (Fig. 2b). We further designed substrate R13/R23-5′ and R23-3′/R13C, which contains 13-nt base pairs and a 10-nt 5′ and 3′ overhang, respectively (Table 1). UAP56 unwinds both substrates with similar efficiencies as the R13/R13C substrate (Fig. 2b). UAP56 unwinds R20/R20C, which contains 20-nt base pairs (Table 1) with significantly less efficiency (roughly ¼ of what is unwound for R13/R13C, Fig. 2b). UAP56’s helicase activity does not have particular sequence specificity, and it unwinds R14/R14C, a 14-nt RNA duplex with completely different sequence than R13/R13C (Table 1). Due to the large amount of UAP56 protein used in the helicase assay, we want to ensure that the unwinding we observed is a genuine helicase activity instead of the trap of ssRNA (generated by dissociation from the dsRNA substrates) by the large amount of UAP56. We performed the helicase assay in the presence of non-hydrolyzable or slowly hydrolyzable ATP analogs (AMPPNP or ATP-γ-S), ADP, TTP, GTP, and CTP (Fig. 2c). ATP hydrolysis is clearly required for the unwinding. The non-hydrolyzable AMP-PNP does not support unwinding, and the slowly hydrolyzable ATP-γ-S demonstrates minimal unwinding (Fig. 2c). TTP, GTP, and CTP cannot be hydrolyzed by UAP56 (Fig. 1e) and do not support dsRNA unwinding either (Fig. 2c). Mutational Analyses of UAP56—Structural and biochemical analyses have suggested some general roles of the conserved helicase motifs in DEXD/H-box proteins. Structures of several DEXD/H-box proteins and other helicases in complex with ADP or ATP analogs show that Lys in motif I (GKT) interacts with the phosphate group of ATP and is important for ATP binding (9Sengoku T. Nureki O. Nakamura A. Kobayashi S. Yokoyama S. Cell. 2006; 125: 287-300Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (448) Google Scholar, 32Shi H. Cordin O. Minder C.M. Linder P. Xu R.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2004; 101: 17628-17633Crossref PubMed Scopus (95) Google Scholar, 40Benz J. Trachsel H. Baumann U. Structure (Camb.). 1999; 7: 671-679Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (110) Google Scholar, 41Caruthers J.M. McKay D.B. Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 2002; 12: 123-133Crossref PubMed Scopus (455) Google Scholar). The Glu in motif II (DEXD) has been postulated to be the key catalytic residue that activates a water molecule to hydrolyze ATP in DEXD/H-box proteins and other helicases (8Cordin O. Banroques J. Tanner N.K. Linder P. Gene (Amst.). 2006; 367: 17-37Crossref PubMed Scopus (739) Google Scholar, 9Sengoku T. Nureki O. Nakamura A. Kobayashi S. Yokoyama S. Cell. 2006; 125: 287-300Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (448) Google Scholar, 41Caruthers J.M. McKay D.B. Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 2002; 12: 123-133Crossref PubMed Scopus (455) Google Scholar). The last Asp residue in motif II and the Ser-Ala-Thr residues in motif III (SAT) do not interact with ATP or RNA but participate in interdomain interactions between the N-terminal and C-terminal domains upon ATP and RNA binding (9Sengoku T. Nureki O. Nakamura A. Kobayashi S. Yokoyama S. Cell. 2006; 125: 287-300Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (448) Google Scholar). These residues were thought to be important for the unwinding activity of DEXD/H-box proteins. In eIF4A, a Lys to Asn mutant in motif I and an Glu to Gln mutant in motif II abolished ATPase activity (42Rozen F. Pelletier J. Trachsel H. Sonenberg N. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1989; 9: 4061-4063Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar, 43Pause A. Methot N. Sonenberg N. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1993; 13: 6789-6798Crossref PubMed Scopus (259) Google Scholar). An Asp to His mutant in the last Asp in motif II (DEAD) and the SAT to AAA mutant in motif III of eIF4A demonstrated a 2–3-fold increase of kcat in ATPase activity but abolished helicase activity (37Pause A. Sonenberg N. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 2643-2654Crossref PubMed Scopus (532) Google Scholar). We generated a number of UAP56 mutants in the conserved helicase motifs I, II, and III and tested their ATPase and helicase activity (Fig. 3a). We found that K95A, GKT/AAA, and E197A mutants of UAP56 completely abolished ATPase activity (Fig. 3b), consistent with the proposed key role of Lys-95 in ATP binding and Glu-197 in ATP hydrolysis. The loss of ATPase activity leads to the abolishment of helicase activity in these mutants (Fig. 3c). The D199A mutant demonstrates increased ATPase activity when compared with the wild type (Fig. 3b). The SAT/AAA mutant behaves somewhat differently from the same mutant in eIF4A and demonstrates significantly decreased ATPase activity (Fig. 3b). The amounts of ATP hydrolyzed by D199A and SAT/AAA are roughly 147% and 32% of the amounts hydrolyzed by wild type UAP56 (Fig. 3b). Both D199A and SAT/AAA mutants completely lost their helicase activity (Fig. 3c), consistent with the hypothesis that these residues are involved in interdomain interactions and are important for the unwinding activity of DEXD/H-box proteins. Potential Influence of UAP56’s ATPase and Helicase Activities by Other Proteins—UAP56 has a genuine but weak ATPase and helicase activity that is similar to eIF4A alone. In the case of eIF4A, the presence of eIF4B and eIF4H stimulates eIF4A’s ATPase (∼3-fold) and helicase activity (4–8-fold) (44Richter-Cook N.J. Dever T.E. Hensold J.O. Merrick W.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 7579-7587Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar, 45Rogers Jr., G.W. Richter N.J. Lima W.F. Merrick W.C. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 30914-30922Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (261) Google Scholar). These stimulations likely contribute to the ability of eIF4A to efficiently unwind secondary structures in the 5′-untranslated region of the mRNA. On the other hand, the weak ATPase activity of eFI4AIII is inhibited by Magoh-Y14, so eIF4AIII can bind to the ssRNA tightly (18Ballut L. Marchadier B. Baguet A. Tomasetto C. Seraphin B. Le Hir H. Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 2005; 12: 861-869Crossref PubMed Scopus (249) Google Scholar). We evaluated here whether UAP56’s ATPase and helicase activity can be affected by protein factors known to interact with UAP56. The two best known protein partners of UAP56 are U2AF65 and Aly. U2AF65 is an essential pre-mRNA splicing factor that recognizes the PYT of an intron (46Zamore P.D. Patton J.G. Green M.R. Nature. 1992; 355: 609-614Crossref PubMed Scopus (459) Google Scholar). UAP56 was first identified through its interaction with U2AF65 using yeast two-hybrid assay, and this interaction was later confirmed using an in vitro pull down assay (22Fleckner J. Zhang M. Valcarcel J. Green M.R. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 1864-1872Crossref PubMed Scopus (213) Google Scholar). The region of U2AF65 that interacts with UAP56 has been mapped to the linker region of U2AF65 (residues 95–138) (22Fleckner J. Zhang M. Valcarcel J. Green M.R. Genes Dev. 1997; 11: 1864-1872Crossref PubMed Scopus (213) Google Scholar). Aly is an export factor that has been shown to interact with UAP56 in vitro and is thought to serve as an adaptor between UAP56 and the heterodimeric transport receptor NXF1-p15 (47Luo M.L. Zhou Z. Magni K. Christoforides C. Rappsilber J. Mann M. Reed R. Nature. 2001; 413: 644-647Crossref PubMed Scopus (308) Google Scholar). We expressed and purified both the human U2AF65 d63 (the N-terminal 62 residues deleted) and GST-Aly from E. coli. U2AF65 d63 and GST-Aly alone do not show any ATPase and helicase activity (Fig. 4). The addition of U2AF65 and GST-Aly to UAP56 does not influence UAP56’s ATPase or helicase activity (Fig. 4). We demonstrated that UAP56 has an RNA-stimulated ATPase activity and that UAP56 can only hydrolyze ATP but not other NTPs. Even with the stimulation of RNA, UAP56's ATPase activity is weak (kcat = 0.25/min), comparable with the weak ATPase activity of eIF4A under similar conditions (kcat = 0.3/min) (36Abramson R.D. Dever T.E. Merrick W.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 6016-6019Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 37Pause A. Sonenberg N. EMBO J. 1992; 11: 2643-2654Crossref PubMed Scopus (532) Google Scholar). The RNA stimulation of UAP56's ATPase activity does not have a strong preference for the sequence and length of the RNA. However, ssRNA stimulates UAP56's ATPase activity much more strongly than dsRNA. dsRNA has been shown to have a weaker stimulatory effect than ssRNA for DEXD/H-box protein RhlE (48Bizebard T. Ferlenghi I. Iost I. Dreyfus M. Biochemistry. 2004; 43: 7857-7866Crossref PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar) but a much stronger stimulatory effect than ssRNA for DEXD/H-box protein p68 (49Huang Y. Liu Z.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 12810-12815Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar). The functional significance, if any, of the stronger stimulation of UAP56's ATPase activity by ssRNA remains to be determined. We also show that UAP56 can unwind short dsRNA (13-nt base pairs) with blunt ends, 5′ overhangs, or 3′ overhangs with similar efficiency and in an ATP hydrolysis-dependent manner. This result does not necessarily conflict with our observation that ssRNA stimulates UAP56’s ATPase activity more strongly than dsRNA. In our helicase assay (which is similar to a typical helicase assay used for other DEXD/H-box proteins such as Vasa (9Sengoku T. Nureki O. Nakamura A. Kobayashi S. Yokoyama S. Cell. 2006; 125: 287-300Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (448) Google Scholar) and eIF4A (39Rogers Jr., G.W. Lima W.F. Merrick W.C. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 12598-12608Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar)), both the dsRNA substrate concentration (2.5 nm) and the single strand trap RNA (100 nm) are too low to have any significant stimulatory effect on UAP56’s ATPase activity. Other DEXD/H-box proteins such as eIF4A and Vasa have also been shown to efficiently unwind substrates with blunt ends (9Sengoku T. Nureki O. Nakamura A. Kobayashi S. Yokoyama S. Cell. 2006; 125: 287-300Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (448) Google Scholar, 39Rogers Jr., G.W. Lima W.F. Merrick W.C. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 12598-12608Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar). Recent structural and biochemical studies have suggested that DEXD/H-box proteins may directly load onto the duplex region and unwind the double strands (for example, by bending RNA), providing a plausible mechanism for the efficient unwinding of blunt end substrates by these DEXD/H-box proteins (9Sengoku T. Nureki O. Nakamura A. Kobayashi S. Yokoyama S. Cell. 2006; 125: 287-300Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (448) Google Scholar, 11Yang Q. Jankowsky E. Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 2006; 13: 981-986Crossref PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar). The unwinding activity of UAP56 does not have sequence specificity and the efficiency of unwinding dramatically reduces with the increasing length of RNA duplexes. The weak ATPase and helicase activity of UAP56 raises the possibility that other protein factors may stimulate this activity and be involved in the in vivo function of UAP56. eIF4B and eIF4H stimulate eIF4A's weak ATPase and helicase activity and likely facilitate eIF4A's function in translation initiation (44Richter-Cook N.J. Dever T.E. Hensold J.O. Merrick W.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 7579-7587Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar, 45Rogers Jr., G.W. Richter N.J. Lima W.F. Merrick W.C. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 30914-30922Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (261) Google Scholar). A recent report demonstrates that Gle1 stimulates the weak ATPase activity of the DEXD/H-box protein Dbp5, and this stimulation is important for Dbp5's function in mRNA export (50Weirich C.S. Erzberger J.P. Flick J.S. Berger J.M. Thorner J. Weis K. Nat. Cell Biol. 2006; 8: 668-676Crossref PubMed Scopus (212) Google Scholar). Inhibition of ATPase activity has also been observed as a possible mode of action for DEXD/H-box proteins (18Ballut L. Marchadier B. Baguet A. Tomasetto C. Seraphin B. Le Hir H. Nat. Struct. Mol. Biol. 2005; 12: 861-869Crossref PubMed Scopus (249) Google Scholar). We show that two of UAP56's interaction partners (U2AF65 and Aly) do not have any influence on UAP56's ATPase and helicase activity. GST-UAP56 pulldown assay brought down components of the Trex complex and several other proteins (hTho2, hHpr1, hTex1, Aly, fSAP79, fSAP35, fSAP24), suggesting direct or indirect interaction between these proteins and UAP56 (30Strasser K. Masuda S. Mason P. Pfannstiel J. Oppizzi M. Rodriguez-Navarro S. Rondon A.G. Aguilera A. Struhl K. Reed R. Hurt E. Nature. 2002; 417: 304-308Crossref PubMed Scopus (645) Google Scholar, 51Masuda S. Das R. Cheng H. Hurt E. Dorman N. Reed R. Genes Dev. 2005; 19: 1512-1517Crossref PubMed Scopus (332) Google Scholar). It remains to be seen whether any of these proteins influence UAP56's weak ATPase and helicase activity. We have analyzed the ATPase and helicase activity of a number of UAP56 mutants in the conserved helicase motifs I to III. UAP56 mutants such as K95A, GKT/AAA, and E197A in motifs I and II completely abolish both the ATPase and the helicase activities. The D199A mutant in motif II uncouples ATPase and helicase activity, which retains high ATPase activity but completely loses helicase activity. These mutants will be valuable tools for deciphering whether the ATPase or helicase activity or both are important for UAP56's function. ATPase and helicase analyses of these mutants also confirm that the ATPase and helicase activity we observed for wild type UAP56 are genuine and do not come from potential E. coli contamination. Although UAP56 is clearly essential for both pre-mRNA splicing and mRNA export, the detailed mechanisms of how UAP56 facilitates splicing and export are unknown. Our biochemical and mutational analyses performed here lay a foundation for further unraveling the role of UAP56's ATPase and helicase activity in pre-mRNA splicing and mRNA export.

Loss of inner ear sensory hair cells (HC) is a leading cause of human hearing loss and balance disorders. Unlike mammals, many lower vertebrates can regenerate these cells. We used cross-species microarrays to examine this process in the avian inner ear. Specifically, changes in expression of over 1700 transcription factor (TF) genes were investigated in hair cells of auditory and vestibular organs following treatment with two different damaging agents and regeneration in vitro. Multiple components of seven distinct known signaling pathways were clearly identifiable: TGFbeta, PAX, NOTCH, WNT, NFKappaB, INSULIN/IGF1 and AP1. Numerous components of apoptotic and cell cycle control pathways were differentially expressed, including p27(KIP) and TFs that regulate its expression. A comparison of expression trends across tissues and treatments revealed identical patterns of expression that occurred at identical times during regenerative proliferation. Network analysis of the patterns of gene expression in this large dataset also revealed the additional presence of many components (and possible network interactions) of estrogen receptor signaling, circadian rhythm genes and parts of the polycomb complex (among others). Equal numbers of differentially expressed genes were identified that have not yet been placed into any known pathway. Specific time points and tissues also exhibited interesting differences: For example, 45 zinc finger genes were specifically up-regulated at later stages of cochlear regeneration. These results are the first of their kind and should provide the starting point for more detailed investigations of the role of these many pathways in HC recovery, and for a description of their possible interactions.

The mechanisms that are responsible for the restricted pattern of expression of the VE-cadherin gene in endothelial cells are not clearly understood. Regulation of expression is under the control of an approximately 140 bp proximal promoter that provides basal, non-endothelial specific expression. A larger region contained within the 2.5 kb genomic DNA sequence located ahead of the transcription start is involved in the specific expression of the gene in endothelial cells. We show here that the VE-cadherin promoter contains several putative hypoxia response elements (HRE) which are able to bind endothelial nuclear factors under normoxia. The VE-cadherin gene is not responsive to hypoxia but hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF)-2alpha specifically activates the promoter while HIF-1alpha does not. The HRE, that are involved in this activity have been identified. Further, we show that HIF-2alpha cooperates with the Ets-1 transcription factor for activation of the VE-cadherin promoter and that this synergy is dependent on the binding of Ets-1 to DNA. This cooperative action of HIF-2alpha with Ets-1 most probably participates to the transcriptional regulation of expression of the gene in endothelial cells. This mechanism may also be involved in the expression of the VE-cadherin gene by tumor cells in the process of vascular mimicry.

Little is known about the molecular basis of somatosensory mechanotransduction in mammals. We screened a library of peptide toxins for effects on mechanically activated currents in cultured dorsal root ganglion neurons. One conopeptide analogue, termed NMB-1 for noxious mechanosensation blocker 1, selectively inhibits (IC50 1 µM) sustained mechanically activated currents in a subset of sensory neurons. Biotinylated NMB-1 retains activity and binds selectively to peripherin-positive nociceptive sensory neurons. The selectivity of NMB-1 was confirmed by the fact that it has no inhibitory effects on voltage-gated sodium and calcium channels, or ligand-gated channels such as acid-sensing ion channels or TRPA1 channels. Conversely, the tarantula toxin, GsMTx-4, which inhibits stretch-activated ion channels, had no effects on mechanically activated currents in sensory neurons. In behavioral assays, NMB-1 inhibits responses only to high intensity, painful mechanical stimulation and has no effects on low intensity mechanical stimulation or thermosensation. Unexpectedly, NMB-1 was found to also be an inhibitor of rapid FM1-43 loading (a measure of mechanotransduction) in cochlear hair cells. These data demonstrate that pharmacologically distinct channels respond to distinct types of mechanical stimuli and suggest that mechanically activated sustained currents underlie noxious mechanosensation. NMB-1 thus provides a novel diagnostic tool for the molecular definition of channels involved in hearing and pressure-evoked pain.

The genus Vitis is represented by several coexisting species in Europe. Our study focuses on naturalised rootstocks that originate in viticulture. The consequences of their presence to the landscape and to native European species (Vitis vinifera ssp. silvestris) are evaluated. This study compares ecological traits (seven qualitative and quantitative descriptors) and the genetic diversity (10 SSR markers) of populations of naturalised rootstocks and native wild grapevines. 18 large naturalised rootstock populations were studied in the Rhône watershed. Wild European grapevines are present in four main habitats (screes, alluvial forests, hedges, and streamside hedges). In contrast, naturalised rootstock populations are mainly located in alluvial forests, but they clearly take advantage of alluvial system dynamics and connectivity at the landscape level. These latter populations appear to reproduce sexually, and show a higher genetic diversity than Vitis vinifera ssp. silvestris. The regrouping of naturalised rootstocks in interconnected populations tends to create active hybrid swarms of rootstocks. The rootstocks show characters of invasive plants. The spread of naturalised rootstocks in the environment, the acceleration of the decline of the European wild grapevine, and the propagation of genes of viticultural interest in natural populations are potential consequences that should be kept in mind when undertaking appropriate management measures.

Although the actin cytoskeleton has been implicated in the control of NADPH oxidase in phagocytosis, very little is known about the cytoskeletal regulation of endothelial NADPH oxidase assembly and activation. Here, we report a role for cortactin and the tyrosine phosphorylation of cortactin in hyperoxia-induced NADPH oxidase activation and ROS production in human pulmonary artery ECs (HPAECs). Exposure of HPAECs to hyperoxia for 3 h induced NADPH oxidase activation, as demonstrated by enhanced superoxide production. Hyperoxia also caused a thickening of the subcortical dense peripheral F-actin band and increased the localization of cortactin in the cortical regions and lamellipodia at cell-cell borders that protruded under neighboring cells. Pretreatment of HPAECs with the actin-stabilizing agent phallacidin attenuated hyperoxia-induced cortical actin thickening and ROS production, whereas cytochalasin D and latrunculin A enhanced basal and hyperoxia-induced ROS formation. In HPAECs, a 3-h hyperoxic exposure enhanced the tyrosine phosphorylation of cortactin and interaction between cortactin and p47phox, a subcomponent of the EC NADPH oxidase, when compared with normoxic cells. Furthermore, transfection of HPAECs with cortactin small interfering RNA or myristoylated cortactin Src homology domain 3 blocking peptide attenuated ROS production and the hyperoxia-induced translocation of p47phox to the cell periphery. Similarly, down-regulation of Src with Src small interfering RNA attenuated the hyperoxia-mediated phosphorylation of cortactin tyrosines and blocked the association of cortactin with actin and p47phox. In addition, the hyperoxia-induced generation of ROS was significantly lower in ECs expressing a tyrosine-deficient mutant of cortactin than in vector control or wild-type cells. These data demonstrate a novel function for cortactin and actin in hyperoxia-induced activation of NADPH oxidase and ROS generation in human lung endothelial cells. In vascular smooth muscle cells, the angiotensin II-mediated activation of NADPH oxidase and ROS generation is regulated in part by p47phox/actin interaction through cortactin; however, the mechanisms of this interaction remain unclear (33Touyz R.M. Yao G. Quinn M.T. Pagano P.J. Schiffrin E.L. Arterioscler. Thromb. Vasc. Biol. 2005; 25: 512-518Crossref PubMed Scopus (138) Google Scholar). In the present study, we have evaluated the role of the actin cytoskeleton and the actin-binding protein cortactin in hyperoxia-induced translocation of p47phox to cell periphery, activation of NADPH oxidase, and generation of ROS/O2ċ¯. Our results demonstrate that (i) small interfering RNA (siRNA) for cortactin and an SH3 domain peptide directed against cortactin were able to block hyperoxia-mediated ROS/O2ċ¯ production; (ii) hyperoxia increased the tyrosine phosphorylation of cortactin and the interaction between cortactin, actin, and p47phox; (iii) knockdown of Src with siRNA decreased hyperoxia-induced phosphorylation of cortactin and the association between p47phox and cortactin; and (iv) cortactin tyrosine phosphorylation at Tyr421, Tyr466, and Tyr482 was essential for the hyperoxia-induced interaction between cortactin and p47phox and ROS/O2ċ¯ production. These results suggest that cortactin may function as a scaffold protein to link and organize the assembly of NADPH oxidase components with the actin cytoskeleton during the generation of ROS in response to hyperoxia in HPAECs. Darwin illustrated his sexual selection theory with male and female morphology of diving beetles, but maintained a cooperative view of their interaction. Present theory suggests that instead sexual conflict should be a widespread evolutionary force driving both intersexual coevolutionary arms races and speciation.We combined Bayesian phylogenetics, complete taxon sampling and a multi-gene approach to test the arms race scenario on a robust diving beetle phylogeny. As predicted, suction cups in males and modified dorsal surfaces in females showed a pronounced coevolutionary pattern. The female dorsal modifications impair the attachment ability of male suction cups, but each antagonistic novelty in females corresponds to counter-differentiation of suction cups in males.A recently diverged sibling species pair in Japan is possibly one consequence of this arms race and we suggest that future studies on hypoxia might reveal the key to the extraordinary selection for female counter-adaptations in diving beetles.

Using cationic liposomes to mediate gene delivery by transfection has the advantages of improved safety and simplicity of use over viral gene therapy. Understanding the mechanism by which cationic liposome:DNA complexes are internalized and delivered to the nucleus should help identify which transport steps might be manipulated in order to improve transfection efficiencies. We therefore examined the endocytosis and trafficking of two cationic liposomes, DMRIE-C and Lipofectamine LTX, in CHO cells. We found that DMRIE-C-transfected DNA is internalized via caveolae, while LTX-transfected DNA is internalized by clathrin-mediated endocytosis, with both pathways converging at the late endosome or lysosome. Inhibition of microtubule-dependent transport with nocodazole revealed that DMRIE-C:DNA complexes cannot enter the cytosol directly from caveosomes. Lysosomal degradation of transfected DNA has been proposed to be a major reason for poor transfection efficiency. However, in our system dominant negatives of both Rab7 and its effector RILP inhibited late endosome to lysosome transport of DNA complexes and LDL, but did not affect DNA delivery to the nucleus. This suggests that DNA is able to escape from late endosomes without traversing lysosomes and that caveosome to late endosome transport does not require Rab7 function. Lysosomal inhibition with chloroquine likewise had no effect on transfection product titers. These data suggest that DMRIE-C and LTX transfection complexes are endocytosed by separate pathways that converge at the late endosome or lysosome, but that blocking lysosomal traffic does not improve transfection product yields, identifying late endosome/lysosome to nuclear delivery as a step for future study.

The DSS1 protein interacts with the breast cancer susceptibility protein BRCA2 that plays an integral role in the repair of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs). DSS1 has also been shown to interact with components of the 26S proteasome in Saccharomyces cerevisiae and in human tumour cells. This raises the possibility of functional interplay between the DNA repair machinery and the proteasome. We show here that human DSS1 interacts with the RPN3 and RPN7 proteasome subunits and define regions of DSS1 important for the interactions with RPN3, RPN7 and BRCA2. We also show that BRCA2 interacts with RPN3 and RPN7 and that the BRCA2/RPN7 interaction is independent of DSS1. Finally, and most significantly, we demonstrate that the proteolytic activity of the proteasome is a determinant of the choice of DSB repair pathway; inhibition of proteasome proteolytic activity results in an increase in the utilization of potentially mutagenic single-strand annealing at the expense of a reduction in the level of error-free gene conversion. This confirms a functional link between DSB repair and proteasomal activity.

The long neck of unconventional myosin V is composed of six tandem “IQ motifs,” which are fully occupied by calmodulin (CaM) in the absence of calcium. Calcium regulates the activity, the folded-to-extended conformational transition, and the processive run length of myosin V, and thus, it is important to understand how calcium affects CaM binding to the IQ motifs. Here we used electron cryomicroscopy together with computer-based docking of crystal structures into three-dimensional reconstructions of actin decorated with a motor domain-two IQ complex to provide an atomic model of myosin V in the presence of calcium. Calcium causes a major rearrangement of the bound CaMs, dissociation of CaM bound to IQ motif 2, and propagated changes in the motor domain. Tryptophan fluorescence spectroscopy showed that calcium-CaM binds to IQ motifs 1, 3, and 5 in a different conformation than apoCaM. Proteolytic cleavage was consistent with CaM preferentially dissociating from the second IQ motif. The enzymatic and mechanical functions of myosin V can, therefore, be modulated both by calcium-dependent conformational changes of bound CaM as well as by CaM dissociation.
